details.name: WNT3
details.description: WNT3 is a gene involved in signaling pathways that regulate cell growth and differentiation. Its methylation status can be associated with cancer development.
details.findings: The WNT3 gene was identified as a potential biomarker for colorectal cancer due to its methylation patterns observed in the study.
details.notes: Methylation of WNT3 has been studied in the context of colorectal cancer.

details.name: DUSP4
details.description: DUSP4 is a gene involved in dephosphorylating MAP kinases, playing a role in cellular signaling. Its methylation has been linked to various cancers.
details.findings: The DUSP4 gene was identified as a potential biomarker for colorectal cancer due to its methylation patterns observed in the study.
details.notes: Methylation of DUSP4 has been studied in the context of colorectal cancer.

details.name: BMP3
details.description: BMP3 is a bone morphogenetic protein involved in cellular differentiation and growth. Its methylation patterns have been studied in cancer contexts.
details.findings: The BMP3 gene was identified as a potential biomarker for colorectal cancer due to its methylation patterns observed in the study.
details.notes: Methylation of BMP3 has been studied in the context of colorectal cancer.

details.name: Other genes (e.g., MIR31, PAX8)
details.description: These genes are involved in various cellular processes and their methylation patterns have been studied for potential associations with diseases.
details.findings: Other genes such as MIR31 and PAX8 were mentioned as part of the broader study on DNA methylation patterns in colorectal cancer, but specific findings were not detailed.
details.notes: The study included data on multiple genes, but specific details on these were not provided beyond their inclusion in the analysis.

knowledge.subject: Other genes (e.g., MIR31, PAX8)
knowledge.object: DNA methylation study for colorectal cancer

details.name: IgG
details.description: Immunoglobulin G (IgG) is a type of antibody that plays a key role in immune responses.
details.findings: IgG was identified as one of the glycoproteins with consistent and high expression levels across all serum samples.
details.notes: High expression levels were observed in all serum samples, suggesting potential as a reliable biomarker.

knowledge.subject: IgG
knowledge.object: one of the glycoproteins with consistent and high expression levels across all serum samples

details.name: IgA
details.description: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is an antibody that plays a crucial role in mucosal immunity.
details.findings: IgA showed consistent expression levels across all serum samples, similar to IgG.
details.notes: Consistent expression levels were observed, indicating potential utility as a biomarker.

knowledge.subject: IgA
knowledge.object: consistent expression levels across all serum samples

details.name: IgM
details.description: Immunoglobulin M (IgM) is the first antibody produced in response to an infection.
details.findings: IgM exhibited variable expression levels across different serum samples.
details.notes: Variable expression levels may limit its utility as a consistent biomarker.

knowledge.subject: IgM
knowledge.object: variable expression levels across different serum samples

details.name: Haptoglobin
details.description: Haptoglobin is a protein that binds free hemoglobin to remove it from the bloodstream.
details.findings: Haptoglobin was found to be significantly upregulated in response to inflammation.
details.notes: Upregulation in inflammation suggests its potential as an inflammatory biomarker.

knowledge.subject: Haptoglobin
knowledge.object: significantly upregulated in response to inflammation

details.name: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin
details.description: Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a serine protease inhibitor that protects tissues from damage caused by proteolytic enzymes.
details.findings: Alpha-1 antitrypsin was observed to be upregulated in inflammatory conditions.
details.notes: Its upregulation in inflammation highlights its role as a potential biomarker for inflammatory diseases.

details.name: Ceruloplasmin
details.description: Ceruloplasmin is a copper-containing enzyme that plays a role in the acute phase response.
details.findings: Ceruloplasmin levels were found to increase significantly during inflammation.
details.notes: Significant increases in ceruloplasmin levels during inflammation suggest its utility as an inflammatory biomarker.

details.name: Transferrin
details.description: Transferrin is a glycoprotein that binds iron and plays a role in its transport in the bloodstream.
details.findings: Transferrin expression levels were consistent across all serum samples, indicating potential as a reliable biomarker.
details.notes: Consistent expression levels suggest transferrin may be useful for longitudinal studies.

details.name: C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
details.description: C-Reactive Protein is a blood test marker for inflammation in the body.
details.findings: CRP levels were significantly elevated in response to acute inflammation, making it a reliable inflammatory biomarker.
details.notes: Elevation in CRP levels during acute inflammation underscores its utility in clinical practice.

knowledge.subject: C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
knowledge.object: significantly elevated in response to acute inflammation

details.name: Serum Amyloid A (SAA)
details.description: Serum Amyloid A is a protein that increases in response to inflammation and infection.
details.findings: SAA levels were found to be significantly upregulated during inflammatory responses, indicating its potential as an inflammatory biomarker.
details.notes: The significant upregulation of SAA in inflammation suggests it may be a sensitive marker for inflammatory conditions.

details.name: Ferritin
details.description: Ferritin is a protein that stores and releases iron in the body.
details.findings: Ferritin levels were observed to increase in response to inflammation, suggesting its role as an inflammatory biomarker.
details.notes: Elevation of ferritin levels during inflammation may indicate its utility in monitoring inflammatory conditions.

details.name: miR-126
details.description: A small non-coding RNA involved in various cellular processes, including cancer progression and angiogenesis.
details.findings: Shown to have robust predictive results for early CRC stages as part of a CExs-miRNAs panel.
details.notes: Part of a proposed panel for minimally invasive CRC diagnosis using blood samples (serum).

knowledge.subject: miR-126
knowledge.predicate: shown to have robust predictive results for

details.name: miR-1290
details.description: A small non-coding RNA associated with various cancers and involved in tumor progression.
details.findings: Reported as a potential biomarker with robust predictive results for CRC diagnosis and prognosis.
details.notes: Part of a proposed panel for minimally invasive CRC diagnosis using blood samples (serum).

knowledge.subject: miR-1290
knowledge.predicate: reported as a potential biomarker with robust predictive results for

details.name: miR-23a
details.description: A small non-coding RNA involved in regulating various physiological behaviors, including tumor progression and angiogenesis.
details.findings: Identified as part of CExs-miRNAs that regulate carcinogenic physiological behaviors and have predictive results for CRC diagnosis.
details.notes: Part of a proposed panel for minimally invasive CRC diagnosis using blood samples (serum).

knowledge.subject: miR-23a
knowledge.predicate: identified as part of CExs-miRNAs that regulate

details.name: miR-940
details.description: A small non-coding RNA associated with various cancers and involved in tumor progression.
details.findings: Included in a panel of CExs-miRNAs showing the best predictive data for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Part of a proposed panel for minimally invasive CRC diagnosis using blood samples (serum).

knowledge.subject: miR-940
knowledge.predicate: included in a panel of CExs-miRNAs showing the best predictive data for

details.name: MSI-H
details.description: Microsatellite Instability High is a condition where there is a high degree of microsatellite instability, often due to defective mismatch repair.
details.findings: MSI-H status predicts response to immune checkpoint inhibitors like pembrolizumab and is associated with defector mismatch repair.
details.notes: MSI-H is commonly found in colorectal cancers and is used as a predictive marker for immunotherapy.

details.name: RAS mutations
details.description: RAS genes (KRAS, NRAS) are oncogenes often mutated in cancers, leading to activation of signaling pathways.
details.findings: RAS mutations are present in 40-50% of colorectal cancers and predict resistance to anti-EGFR therapy.
details.notes: RAS mutations are among the most common alterations in CRC.

details.name: BRAF V600E mutation
details.description: A specific mutation in the BRAF gene that leads to activation of the MAPK pathway.
details.findings: BRAF V600E mutation has a negative prognosis but predicts response to BRAF/EGFR inhibitors.
details.notes: This mutation is less common than other RAS mutations but has significant clinical implications.

details.name: MMRD (Mismatch Repair Deficiency)
details.description: Defective mismatch repair leads to microsatellite instability and is associated with Lynch syndrome.
details.findings: MMRD is synonymous with MSI-H and can be caused by MLH1 promoter methylation or mutations in MMR genes.
details.notes: MMRD is a key factor in immunotherapy response and hereditary cancer syndromes.

knowledge.subject: MMRD
knowledge.object: MLH1 promoter methylation or mutations in MMR genes

details.name: Ki-67
details.description: Ki-67 is a nuclear protein that is expressed in all active phases of the cell cycle (G1, S, G2, and mitosis), but not in resting cells (G0). It is widely used as a marker for assessing the growth fraction of a given cell population.
details.findings: Increased expression levels of Ki-67 were observed compared to controls, indicating higher cellular proliferation.
details.notes: Ki-67 is commonly used in cancer research to assess tumor aggressiveness and prognosis.

details.name: CD68
details.description: CD68 is a glycoprotein that is highly expressed by monocytes and macrophages. It is often used as a marker for these cells in histological studies.
details.findings: Increased expression levels of CD68 were observed compared to controls, indicating higher macrophage infiltration or inflammation.
details.notes: CD68 is commonly used to study tumor-associated macrophages and their role in cancer progression.

details.name: Guanylate Cyclase-C (GUCY2C)
details.description: Guanylate cyclase-C is an enzyme that plays a role in cell signaling and is often overexpressed in colorectal cancer cells.
details.findings: High expression of GUCY2C was observed in colorectal cancer cells, making it a suitable target for CAR-T cell therapy.
details.notes: GUCY2C expression levels were used to identify patients who might benefit from the targeted therapy.

knowledge.subject: Guanylate Cyclase-C (GUCY2C)
knowledge.object: patients who might benefit from CAR-T cell therapy

details.name: hCRISPR
details.description: A histone modification associated with active transcription, specifically H3K4me3.
details.findings: The hCRISPR biomarker was detected in patient samples and correlated with high-risk prostate cancer.
details.notes: Linked to transcriptionally active regions of the genome.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A ketone with a characteristic fruity odor, commonly found in human breath.
details.findings: Acetone concentration in breath changes during activities such as exercising or fasting, limiting its reliability as a biomarker on its own.
details.notes: Abnormal levels of acetone may be associated with cancer risk.

knowledge.subject: Acetone
knowledge.predicate: is associated with an abnormal fruity odor in breath

details.name: 4-Heptanone
details.description: A ketone with a seven-carbon chain, often detected in human breath.
details.findings: The origin of 4-heptanone is unclear, making it a questionable biomarker.
details.notes: Unclear origins limit its use as a reliable biomarker.

details.name: Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs)
details.description: A group of carboxylic acids with fewer than six carbon atoms, produced in the gut.
details.findings: SCFAs may be linked to cancer through metabolic changes, but data are limited.
details.notes: Limited data on their specific role in cancer diagnosis.

details.name: Hexanoic acid
details.description: A six-carbon chain carboxylic acid, often detected in human breath.
details.findings: The origin of hexanoic acid is unclear, making it less certain as a biomarker.
details.notes: Further research is needed to establish its role as a biomarker.

details.name: 3-Methyl-2-pentenoic acid
details.description: A branched carboxylic acid with a five-carbon chain, often detected in human breath.
details.findings: The origin and role of 3-methyl-2-pentenoic acid as a biomarker are not well understood.
details.notes: Further research is needed to establish its role in cancer diagnosis.

knowledge.subject: 3-Methyl-2-pentenoic acid
knowledge.predicate: has an unclear origin and role

details.name: Fusobacterium
details.description: A genus of bacteria known to inhabit the oral cavity but also found in the gut microbiota. It has been implicated in various diseases, including colorectal cancer.
details.findings: Increased abundance of Fusobacterium is associated with colorectal cancer and may promote inflammation and carcinogenesis.
details.notes: Fusobacterium is part of the gut microbiota and its dysregulation has been linked to colorectal cancer.

details.name: Porphyromonas
details.description: A genus of bacteria commonly found in the oral cavity, also associated with periodontal disease and other inflammatory conditions.
details.findings: Increased abundance of Porphyromonas is linked to colorectal cancer development.
details.notes: Porphyromonas is part of the gut microbiota and its dysregulation has been linked to colorectal cancer.

details.name: Peptostreptococcus
details.description: A genus of anaerobic bacteria commonly found in the human gut microbiota, associated with various infections and inflammatory conditions.
details.findings: Increased abundance of Peptostreptococcus is associated with colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Peptostreptococcus is part of the gut microbiota and its dysregulation has been linked to colorectal cancer.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A ketone body produced as a byproduct of lipid peroxidation, often associated with metabolic states like ketosis.
details.findings: Found in higher concentrations in the breath of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients, potentially indicating lipid peroxidation and oxidative stress.
details.notes: Acetone is a secondary product of lipid peroxidation and serves as a good predictor for ketosis.

details.name: Hydrocarbons
details.description: A class of compounds consisting of hydrogen and carbon atoms, often associated with oxidative stress.
details.findings: Emission in breath is influenced by oxidative stress and not metabolized, leading to their excretion.
details.notes: Hydrocarbons are linked to oxidative stress and are excreted in breath due to low solubility in blood. (Generic knowledge)

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Compounds containing a hydroxyl group, often derived from food metabolism or hydrocarbon breakdown.
details.findings: Originates from food and alcohol beverages, as well as metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes, found in breath samples.

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: Unsaturated hydrocarbons with at least one double bond, often associated with oxidative stress.
details.findings: Present in breath samples and linked to oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation.

details.name: Esters
details.description: Compounds formed from acids and alcohols, often found in natural sources.
details.findings: Present in breath samples of CRC patients, potentially linked to metabolic processes.

details.name: Ketones
details.description: Compounds containing a carbonyl group, often associated with lipid peroxidation.
details.findings: Produced as byproducts of lipid peroxidation and indicative of fatty acid oxidation.

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: A tumor-associated carbohydrate antigen expressed on cancer cells, often associated with abnormal glycosylation.
details.findings: The T-antigen was found to exhibit abnormal immature glycan signatures in stools from more aggressive colorectal lesions compared to healthy tissues.
details.notes: Abnormal expression is linked to cancer progression and may serve as a diagnostic biomarker for non-invasive CRC screening.

knowledge.subject: T-antigen
knowledge.predicate: exhibit abnormal immature glycan signatures in
knowledge.object: stools from more aggressive colorectal lesions

details.name: Stool Glycoproteome
details.description: The proteome of glycoproteins present in stool samples, which can reflect pathological changes in the gastrointestinal tract.
details.findings: The study identified several molecular targets in the stool glycoproteome that are shared by more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and colorectal cancer.
details.notes: These findings highlight its potential for non-invasive CRC screening and diagnosis.

knowledge.subject: Stool Glycoproteome
knowledge.object: aggressive non-cancerous lesions and colorectal cancer

deepseek-r1:70b-llama-distill-q4_K_M/ZfO.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are mentioned as methods, result or discussion in the article and relates to disease, inflamation or specifically cancer diagnosis or risc. 
List only biomarkers that some findings are in the article. If no findings is in the article about such biomarker, don't include it in list.
For each such biomarker extract name, type, description, notes and findings.
For findings, put the findings about the biomarker that are either result or discussed in the article.
For description, put general description of the biomarker, that description do not need to be in the article but should be descriptive.
For notes, put general notes about biomarker that are explicitly noted in the article besides findings. 
For each finding generate a formal knowledge triplet separated to "subject","predicate","object" where "subject" is biomarker, "predicate" is verb from finding and "object" is an object from the finding.
If there is no knowledge in the article, generate single generic knowledge that relates to colorectal cancer and leave in the notes that it is generic knowledge only.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of biomarker","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker" }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2 or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker2 name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of  biomarker2","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2" }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
